message_1:
In a study of the survival times of heart transplant patients, 60 patients were followed for up to two years after their surgery. The following table gives the number of patients who survived and the number of patients who died at the end of each of the first 12 months after surgery:

| Months after surgery | Number of patients who survived | Number of patients who died |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | 56 | 4 |
| 2 | 54 | 6 |
| 3 | 50 | 10 |
| 4 | 47 | 13 |
| 5 | 42 | 18 |
| 6 | 38 | 22 |
| 7 | 34 | 26 |
| 8 | 30 | 30 |
| 9 | 25 | 35 |
| 10 | 22 | 38 |
| 11 | 19 | 41 |
| 12 | 16 | 44 |

Using the Kaplan-Meier estimator, what is the estimated probability that a heart transplant patient will survive at least 8 months after surgery?
message_2:
To calculate the Kaplan-Meier estimator, we will use the formula:

S(t) = (number of patients at risk at time t - number of patients who died at time t) / (number of patients at risk at time t)

We will then multiply the survival probabilities at each time point up to 8 months.

S(1) = (56 - 4) / 56 = 52 / 56
S(2) = (54 - 6) / 54 = 48 / 54
S(3) = (50 - 10) / 50 = 40 / 50
S(4) = (47 - 13) / 47 = 34 / 47
S(5) = (42 - 18) / 42 = 24 / 42
S(6) = (38 - 22) / 38 = 16 / 38
S(7) = (34 - 26) / 34 = 8 / 34
S(8) = (30 - 30) / 30 = 0 / 30

Now, we will multiply the survival probabilities at each time point up to 8 months:

S(8) = (52/56) * (48/54) * (40/50) * (34/47) * (24/42) * (16/38) * (8/34) * (0/30)

S(8) = 0

The estimated probability that a heart transplant patient will survive at least 8 months after surgery is 0, which means none of the patients survived past 8 months.
